text:
PAULA HANCOCKS:
The South Koreans

have been going through
this for many, many decades.

They are still
technically at war

with their northern
neighbor, as back in 1953,

there was never a
peace treaty signed.
It was only an armistice.

So this threat of conflict,
a threat of another war
is constant in this country.
But it's also very distant.

It is business as usual when
you consider this is just

one missile launch out
of many missile launches

that we have seen under
this North Korean leader
Kim Jong Un.

It's the fifth launch
this year alone.

But since the
beginning of last year,

there have been about three
dozen missile launches.

There have been
two nuclear tests.

Never in the history
of North Korean testing

have we seen such
intensity and such a rush

from the North
Korean leader to try

and perfect this capability,
both nuclear and missile.

So certainly from
the South Korean

general public's point of
view, nothing much has changed.

We know there's a National
Security Council meeting

ongoing at the moment, the
national security adviser

presiding over that to try
and formulate some kind
of response to what they see.

But of course,
it's very difficult

to see how that response
could change from responses

they have had to give
time and time again
condemning these launches.
